docs.lead_paragraph: VERITAS DGC INC., Houston, a company that collects seismic data for the petroleum industry, agreed to buy the smaller Canadian rival Enertec Resource Services Inc. for $33.5 million. NATIONAL PROPANE PARTNERS L.P., Iowa, saw its shares rise 66 percent, to $11.3125, yesterday, after Columbia Energy Group, a natural-gas distributor, agreed to buy it on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Welfare's sudden death has stunned many residents of the central city here, but few have expressed more dismay than an elderly gentleman on a poverty-pocked block who has been monitoring the neighborhood's civic affairs since the Great Depression. At 86, Frank P. Zeidler is the last of Milwaukee's three Socialist Mayors -- no other major American city has had even one -- and a living link to a time when Wisconsin politics was synonymous with safety-net expansions, like workers' compensation and unemployment insurance.

headline.main: Reforms Punish Poor, Veteran Socialist Says

docs.abstract: Article in occasional series Life After Welfare, on reforms in Wisconsin; 86-year-old Frank P Zeidler, last of Milwaukee's three Socialist Mayors, mourns 'deconstruction' of progress made in early decades of century; sees changes as 'kind of neo-anarchism' that says Government can do nothing right; photos; some of city's leading Democrats disagree, saying reforms build on progressive past that celebrated toil and toilers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It seems self-evident that information about your shoe size does not need to be as well guarded as information about tests ordered by your doctor. But with the Federal and state governments' piecemeal approach to privacy protection, if we release information about one facet of our lives, we inadvertently expose much about the others. During Senate hearings in 1987 about Robert Bork's fitness to serve as a Supreme Court justice, a reporter found out which videotapes Mr. Bork rented. The response was the enactment of the Video Privacy Protection Act. Another law prohibits the Social Security Administration (but hardly anybody else) from releasing our Social Security numbers. Still other laws limit what states can do with information that we provide to motor vehicle departments.
docs.abstract: George Washington University Prof Amitai Etzioni Op-Ed article contends that superpowerful computers and vast databases are threat to individual's privacy; criticizes Federal and state governments for their 'piecemeal approach' to privacy protection; contends that Sun Microsystems chmn Scott McNealy's pronouncement of death of privacy is premature; maintains we will be able to keep it alive only if we introduce general, all-encompassing protections over segmented ones (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Another day, another new mutual fund. The number of fund offerings has exploded in recent years, and the excuses that fund companies give for starting them grow flimsier each day. More and more portfolios are tied to eccentric stock indexes, obscure industry subsectors and ever more esoteric investing styles. The logical end? Following are excerpts from an imaginary annual report: WE at the Dysgenic Family of Funds share your disappointment with our 1998 performance -- even as we remain confident that the stellar returns of our index funds, which came close to matching their appropriate benchmarks if sales loads, 12b-1 fees and management expenses are ignored, amply illustrate the rewards of patience.

headline.main: When an Annual Report Is Hazardous to Your Health

docs.abstract: Article on explosion in mutual fund offerings offers excerpts from imaginary annual report of Dysgenic Family of Funds; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1889, the celebrated and flamboyant New York journalist Nelly Bly set out to travel -- by ship, ox cart, camel, elephant and rickshaw -- around the world in less than 80 days, just topping the fictional record set in Jules Verne's novel. Nowadays, such globe-trotting is much less arduous; with enough money, and a good travel agent, you can do it in less than 48 hours on commercial flights. Yet, curiously, the ''round the world'' idea still retains its air of adventure and romance. The thought of a round-the-world journey excited me even though, after several trips back and forth to Asia, I'd probably covered more total distance last year than in two circumnavigations of the planet. It was the idea of going onward without turning back that appealed, as well as the neatness of always having a goal in sight: home.
docs.abstract: Daisann McLane Frugal Traveler column describes detailed preparations she made before embarking on recent round-the-world trip; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing the dissolution of the state's fourth largest health maintenance organization last week granted 50,000 former policyholders an additional two weeks to find new coverage. Superior Court Judge Jack L. Lintner ruled that those people who had not obtained new coverage by March 31, the day the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey went out of business, would have until April 15. They would be granted coverage retroactively to April 1 if they paid for it.

headline.main: HIP Members Are Given 2 More Weeks to Switch Plans

docs.abstract: New Jersey Superior Court Judge Jack L Lintner, working to dissolve HIP Health Plan, grants 50,000 former members two more weeks to find new coverage (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: BY now, the whole world knows there's no hotter property than companies that make Internet Web sites. Now here's something even hotter: Web sites that make fun of companies. The sites allow disgruntled consumers to, well, express themselves. For example, a site targeting Chase Manhattan Bank features a cartoon of a half-naked little man in red shorts loping across the top of the screen and dropping his drawers before urinating on Chase's name. Mission accomplished, the little man turns and smiles broadly at the viewer.
docs.abstract: Internet sites that make fun of famous companies attract complaints of disgruntled customers, and irate reaction from coroporations that are targeted; photos of sites (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN he sold Hebrew National, the family cold-cuts business, for more than $100 million six years ago, Isadore Pines did not imagine that he would spend his retirement stirring up his neighbors on this idyllic redoubt a short ferry ride south of Miami Beach. Mr. Pines -- whose friends call him Skippy -- seems a most unlikely rebel. He owns a $4.5 million apartment that overlooks the ocean, and he has rickety legs that undermine his tennis game. But like dozens of others here, he believes that plans by the developers who recently bought much of Fisher Island to build 315 lavish condominiums amid the royal palms and banyan trees can only diminish the current residents' quality of life.

headline.main: A Power Struggle in Paradise Pits the Rich Against the Rich

docs.abstract: Article on battle between wealthy residents of exclusive Fisher Island off Miami Beach, led by former Hebrew National owner Isadore Pines, and developers who want to build 315 luxury condominiums; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors issued subpoenas today to 200 hospitals in about 40 states currently or formerly managed by Quorum Health Group Inc. The subpoenas were issued by the Justice Department and by the plaintiff in a lawsuit accusing Quorum of Medicare fraud. They were disclosed by Stephen Meagher, a lawyer for a former employee at a Quorum-managed hospital, and confirmed by a Justice Department spokeswoman. The Government joined the lawsuit last October.
docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors issue subpoenas to 200 hospitals in about 40 states currently or formerly managed by Quorum Health Group Inc; subpoenas are issued by Justice Department and by plaintiff in lawsuit accusing Quorum of Medicare fraud; lawsuit was filed in 1993 by James Alderson, former employee of Quorum-managed hospital in Whitefish, Mont (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House said today that 92 percent of the Federal Government's essential computer systems were free of year 2000 problems, but predicted that Americans would have difficulty reaching some foreign countries by telephone or airplane, because some computers overseas would not be fixed by early next year. Today was the Administration's self-imposed deadline for finishing the renovation and repair of Federal computers so they will operate properly next year.
docs.abstract: White House says 92 percent of Federal Govt's essential computer systems are free of year 2000 problems, but predicts Americans would have difficulty reaching some some foreign countries by telephone or airplane since some computers overseas will not be fixed by early in year; John A Koskinen, White House official supervising computer preparations, says 13 major Federal departments and agencies will meet April 1 deadline, but that 11 others will miss it; Sen Robert F Bennett, head of Senate Special Committee on the Year 2000 Technology Problem, cites examples of systems that were supposed to be fixed by April 1, but are not yet ready (M)
